description:
Principles for effective risk data aggregation and risk reporting

BCBS 239 was created in response to the 2007 GFC, which exposed that IT and data architectures within and across banks were inadequate to support the broad management of financial risks. In order for banks to have complete visibility on their risk exposure, the Basel Committee defined 14 key principles that were made into BCBS. The 14 principles can be classified into 4 categories: governance, infrastructure, risk data aggregation capabilities, reporting capabilities, and prudential supervision. 

Governance and Infrastructure is the deployment of data quality governance systems to improve financial communication and the production of more accurate and relevant reports in order to speed up and make decision-making processes more reliable.

Risk Data aggregation capabilities affects the IT infrastructure and requires banks to put in place a data architecture that enables the automation and reliability of the data aggregation chain. *

description:
Markets in Financial Instruments Directive

MiFID is a European regulation that increases the transparency across the European Union’s financial markets and standardizes the regulatory disclosures required for firms operating in the EU. MiFID I and II has 3 key regulations. 

1-Client classification: 
3 categories: retail clients, professionals, and eligible counter parties 
Professional & Retail are considered capable of making their own investment decisions and evaluate the risks present in the decisions; have knowledge, experience, expertise 
Eligible counter parties are the most sophisticated investor participants and are subject to less regulatory protection by virtue of their financial capacities, knowledge, and capabilities  (investment firms, credit institutions, insurance companies)

2- Pre-trade and Post-trade transparency 
Pre-trade Transparency: those who operate order-matching systems must make information regarding the 5 best pricing levels (on both the buy and sell side) available to all. Those who run quote-driven markets must make the best bids and offers publicly available 
Post-trade Transparency: requires that firms release information regarding the price, time, and volume of all trades pertaining to listed shares, even if they are not executed in an open market scenario 

3-Requires that investment firms complete “best execution” when dealing with all transactions
Firms must strive to achieve the highest price for its client but also tries to limit costs and the time taken to complete a transaction 

Effects:
Increased the transparency of the investment market
Previously, investment firms were only able to gather information from one or two different exchanges that were made public BUT NOW they are able to gather information from all outlets that have publicly released their prices/details. THEREFORE, this adds a lot of unexpected work, so in order to deal with this issue, financial data vendors have become popular - they help the financial institutions deal with the fragmentation of information and enable them to have access to as many details as possible

description:
Bank Secrecy Act / Anti-Money Laundering 

Created in 1970 
Objective: Combat money laundering and the financing of terrorism in the U.S
How:
5 Pillars of BSA AML Compliance enforced by the Financial Crimes Enforcement Network (FinCEN)
Internal Controls - examine factors like geographic location, types of services officers, and customers served
Designation of a BSA AML officer
Establishment of BSA AML training program
Independent testing of compliance program - use a third party to annually test compliance policy
Customer Due Diligence (CDD) - verify customer’s identity, assess their risk, understand their general financial habits
Reporting/Filing Obligations with FinCEN
Currency Transaction Reports (CTR): must be filed for cash transactions $10,000+
Form 8300: must be filed when certain businesses receive $10,000+ in a single transaction or multiple related transactions within 24 hours
Suspicious Activity Reports (SAR): transactions which involve suspected BSA violations or terrorist financing activties with $5,000+
Foreign Bank and Financial Account Report (FBAR): annual filing requirement for individuals holding accounts with foreign banks of $10,000+
